sourceDesc.p: Born digital. Words and definitions taken from original handwritten lexis at (versions I–VII) and the RedBook (version VIII). In the latter case, original word-forms and not their later Jastugay renditions are recorded. Commentary added.

projectDesc.p: Comprehensive linguistic reference for the various LANGDEV languages.

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to separate the different versions of the Jastulae language, and categorize words within later versions. Also used to contain preface material.
The BCP47 type marks an IETFInternet Engineering Task Force language tag, as defined by BCPBest Current Practices 47.
Marks keywords for entry indexing and searching.
The version type is used to denote versions in the list of changes.
The unicode type is used to reference a Unicode character.
The splash type refers to an optional splash quote. A splash with subtype default identifies the default splash; all others are alternates.

html:footer.html:p:
Written in TEI and styled as HTML using XSLT+CSS.

html:aside.html:strong: WARNING: Duplicate xml:id found for entry #!!!

revisionDesc.change: Set internal tag usage counts to their correct values. 1.02
Created TEIText Encoding Initiative document from source text and prior work. This is the first full digitization of the entire known Jastulae language. 1.01

div.p: Jastulae is an early culture and language in the Jastu-Sevensi language family. The Unicode character U+22BB ⊻ XOR has traditionally been used as a shorthand for Jastulae.

The words below are grouped into eight generations based on their approximate times of use. The earliest of these are categorized as ⊻ I and the latest as ⊻ VIII. Jastugay is a close sibling language to Jastulae, and Jastugay VIII and ⊻ VIII were extant during the same time period.

Definitive etymological classifications for early Jastulae words are not made; rather, broad associations have been noted. These are marked via a U+223B ∻ HOMOTHETIC Unicode character. In later iterations of the language, etymological history becomes much more clear.

The entries below use a roughly phonetic spelling; however, as Jastulae is in essence a speculative proto-language, the pronunciation data should not be taken as anything more than a broad guideline. Interested persons should research the phonologies of Jastugay and Classical Sevensi for more information on how these sounds have evolved over time.

Jastulae has been given the language code art-x-jtl. As with any language using the art tag, specifying the Latn script may prove useful. The sibling language Jastugay developed a native script, but likely not until after the period in which Jastulae was spoken.

entry.def: An ocean or very large body of water
entry.note: Smaller lakes and seas are referred to simply as the water
Note: Pronounced as a combination of s and h sounds, not with a sh sound
Note: Earlier etymological records mark this word as descending from hīatsō, but hīatsē is the correct spelling

sense.def: Free of obstructioin or impurity, as in, a dāħetə sky

entry.note: Note: There is no word for black. Dark is used instead.

entry.etym: Made up, w/ infl. by VII +
